rows.title: Counting sounds

transcript.eng:
Sit down and close your eyes.
How many sounds can you hear?  
Listen to the sounds inside and outside the room. Count them on your fingers. 
After ten seconds, how many fingers do you have up? What sounds did you hear? 

Try again for another ten seconds.  
Did you hear any new sounds? Did you hear any sounds inside your own body? 
Notice how you feel now.

rows.transcript:
Sit down and close your eyes.
How many sounds can you hear?  
Listen to the sounds inside and outside the room. Count them on your fingers. 
After ten seconds, how many fingers do you have up? What sounds did you hear? 

Try again for another ten seconds.  
Did you hear any new sounds? Did you hear any sounds inside your own body? 
Notice how you feel now.

text_1.eng: Take a moment to check in with yourself.

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Wonderful, I am so happy things are going well.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Some days will have their challenges. That is okay. You are on the right path!

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Sorry that things are difficult now. It is completely normal to struggle sometimes. Remember that you are not alone!

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Today's topic is about problem solving. 

Every family faces challenges, but when we work together we can deal with problems in an effective and peaceful way.

What a great skill for your teen to learn too!

media_title.eng: How can problem solving help you and your family?

media_transcript.eng:
Greetings, everyone.

Today's topic is problem solving.

We all know that in life there are times where we face problems, and we all know in a way that when we find ourselves in these situations, it is difficult to think of immediate positive solutions.

Therefore, it is important that when we are facing problems we take a pause, we breathe, keep calm and think of problem-solving skills that we may use.

Remember to include our teenagers when we are solving problems. This will help them to become responsible and learn how to solve their own problems in the future.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today's topic is about problem solving. 

Every family faces challenges, but when we work together we can deal with problems in an effective and peaceful way.

What a great skill for your teen to learn too!
rows.media_title: How can problem solving help you and your family?
rows.media_transcript:
Greetings, everyone.

Today's topic is problem solving.

We all know that in life there are times where we face problems, and we all know in a way that when we find ourselves in these situations, it is difficult to think of immediate positive solutions.

Therefore, it is important that when we are facing problems we take a pause, we breathe, keep calm and think of problem-solving skills that we may use.

Remember to include our teenagers when we are solving problems. This will help them to become responsible and learn how to solve their own problems in the future.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
As parents, we sometimes think we need to fix every problem by ourselves. And teens can think the same! 

By involving your teen, you strengthen your relationship as well as their confidence. Together you can overcome anything.

media_title.eng: Can problem solving keep your teens safe? It did for @data.characters.media_female_4.name - tap play to hear her story

media_transcript.eng:
I did not have a good relationship with my daughter. I was always shouting at her, and she was refusing to go to school.

Only when I started spending One-on-One time with her, I realised that she did not want to go to school because she was being bullied at school. We sat down and used the 6 steps of problem solving. We identified the problem, and figured out solutions together: “What can I do as a parent so you can attend school and feel safe?”

We agreed I would go talk to the teacher to find a way forward. We really found the solutions together, and we are closer now.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
As parents, we sometimes think we need to fix every problem by ourselves. And teens can think the same! 

By involving your teen, you strengthen your relationship as well as their confidence. Together you can overcome anything.
rows.media_title: Can problem solving keep your teens safe? It did for @data.characters.media_female_4.name - tap play to hear her story
rows.media_transcript:
I did not have a good relationship with my daughter. I was always shouting at her, and she was refusing to go to school.

Only when I started spending One-on-One time with her, I realised that she did not want to go to school because she was being bullied at school. We sat down and used the 6 steps of problem solving. We identified the problem, and figured out solutions together: “What can I do as a parent so you can attend school and feel safe?”

We agreed I would go talk to the teacher to find a way forward. We really found the solutions together, and we are closer now.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s look at what happened to @data.characters.f1_daughter_13.name and her mother when @data.characters.f1_daughter_13.name got a phone from a boy… Can you believe it!

character_1_text.eng: @data.characters.f1_daughter_13.name, where did you get that thing?

character_2_text.eng: @data.characters.man_threat.name bought it for me. It’s a nice phone, @data.characters.f1_mother.role_name. It takes great photos!

character_1_text.eng: I don’t want to see that expensive thing! That boy is no good! How does he think you are going to repay him for this?!

text_1_facilitator.eng:
When you face a problem, take a few deep breaths to help you stay calm. 
Then, try to handle the problem using these four steps!

section_2_text.eng: Think of possible solutions and what would happen if we used them.

section_3_text.eng: Choose a solution and try it out.

section_4_text.eng: Did it work? Great! If it did not work, then try another solution.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
When you face a problem, take a few deep breaths to help you stay calm. 
Then, try to handle the problem using these four steps!
rows.section_2_text: Think of possible solutions and what would happen if we used them.
rows.section_3_text: Choose a solution and try it out.
rows.section_4_text: Did it work? Great! If it did not work, then try another solution.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s see how problem solving works in real life— using this week’s 4 steps: know it, solve it, try it, and test it.

character_1_text.eng: (🤔_thinking_) Ay my poor feet! I need to sit down for a moment and drink a cup of coffee before I start preparing food for everyone.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Let’s see how problem solving works in real life— using this week’s 4 steps: know it, solve it, try it, and test it.
rows.character_1_text: (🤔_thinking_) Ay my poor feet! I need to sit down for a moment and drink a cup of coffee before I start preparing food for everyone.

character_1_text.eng: @data.characters.f2_son_15.name! What are you doing? That bread is for dinner! Now there will not be enough for us all!

rows.character_1_text: @data.characters.f2_son_15.name! What are you doing? That bread is for dinner! Now there will not be enough for us all!

character_1_text.eng: Sorry, @data.characters.f2_grandmother.role_name, I was just hungry. I can explain, you see, there is this guy at school...

rows.character_1_text: Sorry, @data.characters.f2_grandmother.role_name, I was just hungry. I can explain, you see, there is this guy at school...

character_1_text.eng: Just give me a moment. I am tired and now worried about having enough food for dinner.

rows.character_1_text: Just give me a moment. I am tired and now worried about having enough food for dinner.

character_1_text.eng: Now tell me, why are you so hungry? Did you not eat your lunch at school?

character_2_text.eng: That is the problem. There is a guy at school who bullies me. He says if I do not give my lunch to him every day, he and his friends will hurt me. He makes me so mad!

rows.character_1_text: Now tell me, why are you so hungry? Did you not eat your lunch at school?
rows.character_2_text: That is the problem. There is a guy at school who bullies me. He says if I do not give my lunch to him every day, he and his friends will hurt me. He makes me so mad!

character_1_text.eng: I am sorry to hear that but am glad that you told me, @data.characters.f2_son_15.name. It does not mean that you can eat everybody’s dinner. After we speak, you need to go to the shop to buy some more bread. But first, what do you think we should do about the bully problem?

character_2_text.eng: Well… I want to just hit him or get him back.

rows.character_1_text: I am sorry to hear that but am glad that you told me, @data.characters.f2_son_15.name. It does not mean that you can eat everybody’s dinner. After we speak, you need to go to the shop to buy some more bread. But first, what do you think we should do about the bully problem?
rows.character_2_text: Well… I want to just hit him or get him back.

character_1_text.eng: Hmmm… what do you think will happen to you if you do that?

character_2_text.eng: I don’t know. He is bigger than me so he will probably hurt me more. And I could get into trouble at school and get expelled.

character_1_text.eng: Yes, that could happen. What could we do instead?

character_2_text.eng: I guess I could tell the teacher. But then the other kids will call me a snitch. Maybe you could talk to the teacher?

rows.character_1_text: Yes, that could happen. What could we do instead?
rows.character_2_text: I guess I could tell the teacher. But then the other kids will call me a snitch. Maybe you could talk to the teacher?

character_1_text.eng: That sounds like a better idea. I could also have a word with his parents if you want me to.

character_2_text.eng: Sure. If you think that would help too. Thanks, @data.characters.f2_grandmother.role_name.

rows.character_1_text: That sounds like a better idea. I could also have a word with his parents if you want me to.
rows.character_2_text: Sure. If you think that would help too. Thanks, @data.characters.f2_grandmother.role_name.

character_1_text.eng: Anything for you, my dear. I will do it first thing after dinner. And you know? If that does not work, we can always try something else together.

rows.character_1_text: Anything for you, my dear. I will do it first thing after dinner. And you know? If that does not work, we can always try something else together.

character_1_text.eng: How are things going at school now?

character_2_text.eng: It is going better, the boy does not take my lunch anymore. But he is still being really mean to me.

rows.character_1_text: How are things going at school now?
rows.character_2_text: It is going better, the boy does not take my lunch anymore. But he is still being really mean to me.

character_1_text.eng: I am sorry to hear that, @data.characters.f2_son_15.name. Shall I ask your uncle to go talk to his parents? If that does not work, we will try something else!

character_2_text.eng: Yes, thank you, @data.characters.f2_grandmother.role_name. At least I know you are on my side.

rows.character_1_text: I am sorry to hear that, @data.characters.f2_son_15.name. Shall I ask your uncle to go talk to his parents? If that does not work, we will try something else!
rows.character_2_text: Yes, thank you, @data.characters.f2_grandmother.role_name. At least I know you are on my side.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
That was a great example of how to solve a problem!  

Now let’s remember what happened with @data.characters.f1_daughter_13.name and the phone she got from the boy.

How could @data.characters.f1_daughter_13.name and her mother, @data.characters.f1_mother.name, use the 4 steps of problem solving to come up with solutions, just like @data.characters.f2_grandmother.name and @data.characters.f2_son_15.name did?

text_2.eng:
**Remember, you can use the 4 steps to solve problems:**

💭 Step 1: KNOW IT (identify problem)
📋 Step 2: SOLVE IT (identify solutions) 
⚒️ Step 3: TRY IT (try one) 
🎯 Step 4: TEST IT (try another solution if this one did not work)

text_1_facilitator.eng:
When something bad happens, we often get upset and blame. But what our teens really need is someone to help find solutions together. 

Listen to them, accept how they see and feel things, and thank them for trusting you.

Teaching your teen how to deal with problems will help them for the rest of their lives. What a gift!

text_2.eng:
**Here are some examples of problems other parents solved with their teens:**

- My teenager does not want to go to school
- I am worried my teenager will get pregnant or will get someone pregnant
- I am worried about what my teen does online
- My teenager is hanging out with bad friends
- My teenager is lazy
- My teenager is not doing their school work
- My teenager might be using drugs

rows.text_1_facilitator:

Teaching your teen how to deal with problems will help them for the rest of their lives. What a gift!

- My teenager does not want to go to school

- My teenager is hanging out with bad friends
- My teenager is lazy
- My teenager is not doing their school work
- My teenager might be using drugs

text_1_facilitator.eng: Your home activity this week is to teach your teenagers the steps for problem-solving and use them together when a problem comes up.

text_2.eng:
**Remember to use the four steps of problem-solving:** 
💭 Step 1: KNOW IT (identify problem)
📋 Step 2: SOLVE IT (identify solutions) 
⚒️ Step 3: TRY IT (try one) 
🎯 Step 4: TEST IT (try another solution if this one did not work)

quiz_1_question.eng: Can you solve one problem together with your teen this week - using the four steps?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: That's great! Working together with your teen will bring so many good outcomes for you both.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: You can do it! Try it out with a ‘small’ problem that may come up, so you can see how it works before tackling a bigger challenge.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: That's okay. Just remember that when a situation feels overwhelming, it can really help to use the four steps of problem solving with your teen to break the problem down.

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: That's great! Working together with your teen will bring so many good outcomes for you both.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: You can do it! Try it out with a ‘small’ problem that may come up, so you can see how it works before tackling a bigger challenge.

rows.quiz_1_question: Can you solve one problem together with your teen this week - using the four steps?
rows.text_1_facilitator: Your home activity this week is to teach your teenagers the steps for problem-solving and use them together when a problem comes up.
rows.text_2:
**Remember to use the four steps of problem-solving:** 
💭 Step 1: KNOW IT (identify problem)
📋 Step 2: SOLVE IT (identify solutions) 
⚒️ Step 3: TRY IT (try one) 
🎯 Step 4: TEST IT (try another solution if this one did not work)

text_1_facilitator.eng:
We all have problems, but they don’t define us! You can choose to address challenges and try different solutions together with your teen. 
This shows your teen that they are never alone and gives them a key skill to use at home, with friends, and for life!

media_title.eng: Can you make an impact on your community with these skills? Hear @data.characters.media_son_2.name's story

media_transcript.eng:
When my father introduced the problem-solving steps to me, it helped me with my family, but it also helped me with my friends.

I told my friends about the steps, and now when we are arguing we sit down and everyone comes up with solutions. We then look for the negatives and positives of each solution, and we agree “okay let’s try this one.”

My friends even took it to their own homes, and it is helping with their families as well!

It is great when others listen to you and accept your ideas even though you are young. We can all bring that harmony with our friends and family.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
We all have problems, but they don’t define us! You can choose to address challenges and try different solutions together with your teen. 
This shows your teen that they are never alone and gives them a key skill to use at home, with friends, and for life!
rows.media_title: Can you make an impact on your community with these skills? Hear @data.characters.media_son_2.name's story
rows.media_transcript:
When my father introduced the problem-solving steps to me, it helped me with my family, but it also helped me with my friends.

I told my friends about the steps, and now when we are arguing we sit down and everyone comes up with solutions. We then look for the negatives and positives of each solution, and we agree “okay let’s try this one.”

My friends even took it to their own homes, and it is helping with their families as well!

It is great when others listen to you and accept your ideas even though you are young. We can all bring that harmony with our friends and family.
